title: Motivation
text: motivation stems need free, open source option analyzing textual qualitative data. Textual qualitative data refers text interview transcripts, observation notes, memos, jottings primary source/archival documents. Qualitative data analysis (QDA) processes, particularly developed Corbin Strauss (2014), Miles, Huberman, Saldana (2013), Glaser Strauss (2017), can thought layering interpretation onto text. researcher starts open coding, meaning free tag snippets text whatever descriptions deems appropriate. instance, researcher coding observation notes senses conversations two individuals relevant research questions, might tag instances two individuals speak code “conversation.” next round coding, might classify participants discuss finer tag, like “conversation_package” talking creating packages R. another round, might get even specific codes “conversation_package_nomoney” participant discussed money create package R. Later rounds involve conflating codes might mean thing, relating codes one another (often documenting meanings similar way software documentation), eliminating codes longer make sense. Sometimes QDA process involves looking instances demonstrate concept, mechanism, theory academic literature subject. approach common toward end process fields organization studies, management, disciplines prominent approach beginning fields experimental clinical roots (e.g., psychology). Using software QDA allows researchers nest codes, begin see number instances particular code applied. Perhaps importantly, software allows easy visualization analysis codes co-occur (.e., multiple codes applied snippets text), linking activities help researchers identify specify themes data. software packages allow researcher visualize codes relationships new innovative ways; however, cursory review literature suggests qualitative researchers often use basic features; even use software Endnote Microsoft Word even analog systems paper sticky notes. QDA iterative process. Researchers often change, lump together, split, re-organize codes analyze data. Depending coding approach, researchers might also create codebook research notes code defines code specifies instances code applied.

title: Motivation
text: date, researchers conduct QDA largely rely upon proprietary software listed . Free open source options limited, easy integrate R (credit bduckles descriptions): NVivo - QSR International Desktop based software Windows Mac support. Functionality includes video images data auto-coding processes. Tech support training available relatively large user base. Atlas.TI Desktop based software Mac Windows, also mobile apps android iOS. Similar functionality NVivo including using video visuals data. training support. MAXQDA Desktop based software works Mac Windows. Training several tiers licenses available. QDA Miner - Provalis Research Windows application analyze qualitative text, can used visuals well. also “lite” package free. HyperResearch - Researchware Desktop based software works Mac Windows. Dedoose Web based software, usable platform. Data stored web instead device. Includes text, photos, audio, video spreadsheet information. Annotations Mac app allows highlight, keyword create notes text documents. inexpensive way basic qualitative data analysis. Last updated 2014. RQDA QDA package R free open source. Bugs program make challenging use. Last updated 2012. Coding Analysis Toolkit - CAT free, web based, open source service created University Pittsburgh. Can used platform. supported. Weft QDA free open source Windows program support. website says bugs program can result loss data.

title: Motivation
text: extant software package limitations. foremost limitation cost, can prohibit students underfunded qualitative researchers conducting analyses systematically, efficiently. Furthermore, mature software packages (e.g., Atlas.TI, NVIVO) offer features exceed needs many users , result, suffer speed issues (particularly researchers may benefit advanced hardware). sharing process proprietary QDA outputs equally unwieldy, relying non-intuitive bundling unbundling processes, steep learning curves, non-transferable skill development. Open source languages R offer opportunity involve qualitative researchers open source software development. Greater involvement qualitative researchers serves expand scope R users create inroads connect qualitative quantitative R packages. instance, better integration qualitative research packages R make possible existing text analysis programs work alongside qualitative coding.

title: Motivation
text: began project rOpenSci’s runconf18 based bduckles issue. began discussing common challenges peers face conducting QDA considering might learn existing quantitative text analysis open source packages. identified number unique challenges qualitative researchers encounter analyzing data. GUI broader adoption. Quantitative researchers often familiar conducting analyses command line. Qualitative researchers, hand, often rely upon Graphical User Interfaces (GUI) perform analysis tasks. proposed, -development solution integrating Shiny apps permit personalized GUI QCoder. Collaboration. Several aspects collaboration qualitative research present challenges development use QDA software. first challenge relates version control tracking changes. Whereas contributors open source software community, perhaps software development community generally, developed processes sharing code, data, work products, qualitative researchers often rely email, DropBox/box, sharing technologies lack appropriate version control features. One proposed solution implement system record-keeping maintains files akin Atlas.TI’s bundling unbundling process, permits simultaneous work comparison/merging changes. might also consider urging users learn git facilitate skill development offering tutorials. second collaboration challenge relates need establish inter-rater inter-coder reliability. Existing methods assessing inter-rater reliability QDA include Cronbach’s Alpha Krippendorff’s Alpha, among others. evaluations, though, account complexities decisions code segment text. words, deciding apply code snippet text might considered equivalent level agreement decision apply code snippet text. QCoder aims make inter-rater reliability assessments easier effective traditional approaches allowing direct comparisons differences codebooks generates. Privacy concerns. Qualitative data often includes personally-identifying information. Quantitative approaches deidentification always applicable qualitative datasets text-based data includes rich descriptions may elevate risk re-identification. Furthermore, qualitative data tends unstructured ways make systematic approaches de-identification difficult implement. QDA software, , needs account complexities. Reproducibility. Qualitative research communities, particularly communities employing methods probe human social behavior (ethnography), fiercely debate whether qualitative research meant reproducible. words, researchers argue human social behavior contextually bound moments time, physical settings, generally fluid nature phenomena study. Accepting dispute valid, striving develop package can facilitate level reproduction data analysis. approach centers production codebooks. Qualitative researchers create codebooks coding data. codebooks match code description code used. creation codebook iterative process concurrent coding process. Codes routinely combined, split shifted researcher analysis. Codebooks way researcher indicate members research team apply codes data. Historically, code books standard across different QDA packages. benefit standard codebook format compared across projects even project iterates. Using Git version control codebook created prevent mistakes teaching learning tool qualitative research. Additionally, codebooks contain sensitive private data shared made publicly available. One envision capacity researchers share codebooks research follows draw existing codes future research. key characteristic QCoder exposes QDA processes critique ways proprietary software excludes. example, unreasonable expect researchers interested reviewing reproducing analysis done manuscript pay license perform task hand. QCoder can easily installed potentially maintained critical mistakes analysis might caught corrected review processes. Money. disciplines qualitative work occurs enjoy level funding , say, natural sciences engineering. Expensive software packages, , may available researchers. case equally dire students researchers -resourced communities countries. R-based QDA package enables broader participation qualitative research , extension, broader perspectives nature human social behavior.

None grants Questa sent come back money research. ’s discouraged passionate work knows needs finish chapter dissertation can graduate already. ’s done work nonprofit support work. ’s pretty sure postdoc finishes degree. able hire support research, ’s unlikely ’d enough funds get license one QDA packages. able try larger QDA packages work ok student license, computer last legs program keeps crashing computer. ’s planning start interviews overall thinks ’ll maybe around 50-75 text files include 1) codes conduct 2) interview transcripts 3) field research conference. ’s sure many codes ’d need, ’s guessing first round coding lot different codes – maybe 150 – 200 codes start. ’d likely change boil groups codes categories codes. ideally program make easy edit, change move around codes. also needs write simple codebook coding.

title: Motivation
text: Corbin, J., & Strauss, . L. (2014). Basics qualitative research. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. Glaser, B. G., & Strauss, . L. (2017). Discovery grounded theory: Strategies qualitative research. London, UK: Routledge. Miles, M. B., & Huberman, . M. (1994). Qualitative data analysis: expanded sourcebook. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. Miles, M. B., Huberman, . M., & Saldana, J. (2013). Qualitative data analysis. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. Saldana, J. (2015). coding manual qualitative researchers. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.

text: document string scanned errors.

title: Check for coding errors — error_check
text: warning message character string.

title: Check for coding errors — error_check
text: function takes string (contents document), conducts basic linting. returns warning matching number (QCODE) tags, text marked captured capture missing tag (missing {#my_tag}).

title: Check for coding errors — error_check
code: error_check("An (QCODE)unmatched set of (QCODE) gives (/QCODE){#tag} a warning.") #> Warning: WARNING: number of (QCODE) and (/QCODE) tags do not match #>             in document ; erroneous output is likely. error_check("A (QCODE) qcode with a missing tag gives a warning.") #> Warning: WARNING: number of (QCODE) and (/QCODE) tags do not match #>             in document ; erroneous output is likely.

title: Parse coded text — parse_qcodes

text: x data frame containing text coded; requires columns "doc_id" "document_text" ... parameters optionally passed

title: Parse coded text — parse_qcodes
text: data frame contains coded text document_text column, output data frame three columns: "doc", "qcode", "text".
code: The \code{doc} is the \code{doc_id} from the input data frame.      \code{qcode} is the code that the captured text was marked up with.      \code{text} is the text that was captured.

title: Parse coded text — parse_qcodes
text:
function takes text document containing coded text form: turns data frame one row per coded item, form: docid,qcode,text parse_qcodes assumes passed data frame, parse_one_document function called heavy lifting extracting coded text document_text column. Newline characters replaced HTML
captured text. valid qcodes found, parse_qcodes returns empty data frame (rows).
code: "stuff to ignore (QCODE) coded text we care about (/QCODE){#my_code} more stuff to ignore"

title: Parse coded text — parse_qcodes
code: parse_qcodes(my_documents) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'my_documents' not found  # Data frames can be piped into this function my_documents %>%   parse_qcodes() #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'my_documents' not found

title:

Use this if you have a spreadsheet of codes already created. — read_code_data
text: project_name Name project, matches folder name data_path Path file containing  code data csv. df_path Full path codes data frame. data_frame_name name RDS file data frame stored . project_path Full path project folder

title:
Create a file of codes from csv file
Use this if you have a spreadsheet of codes already created. — read_code_data
code: create_qcoder_project(project_name = "_my_qcoder_project", sample = TRUE) read_code_data(project_name = "_my_qcoder_project") unlink("./_my_qcoder_project", recursive=TRUE)

"
